conclusion: The problem involves determining the initial distance between two cars from a velocity-time graph where they just avoided colliding.
Car A starts at 25 m/s and reaches 0 m/s at t = 25 s; Car B starts at 15 m/s and reaches 0 m/s at t = 30 s; They have the same velocity (approximately 5 m/s) at t = 20 s.
Calculate the distance Car A travels from t = 0 to t = 25 s using the area under the v-t graph.
Distance Car A travels is 312.5 m.
Calculate the distance Car B travels from t = 0 to t = 25 s using average velocity.
Distance Car B travels is 218.75 m.
Determine the initial distance where they just avoid collision: 218.75 m - 312.5 m = -93.75 m.
The negative value indicates Car A was 93.75 m ahead of Car B's starting position.
For a collision to occur, the initial distance must be less than 93.75 m.
The initial distance between the cars that would result in a collision is any distance less than 93.75 meters.
